question: "And let me play among the stars.." Any moment now. On the right. "Let me see what spring is like..." "..on Jupiter and Mars.." We've something else to do first. Won't take long.
answer: Today we welcome Brian Clough as he starts his new job as manager of Leeds United, taking over from Don Revie - the most successful manager in the club's history, under whom Leeds have won everything..

question: ..not QUITE everything. Not won the European Cup...
answer: ...but pretty much everything else. Daunted?

question: Daunted? Not at all, Austin. Looking forward to it.
answer: The biggest challenge of your life, and you'll be without Peter Taylor, for the first time. Your lifelong professional colleague.

question: Yes, Pete's at Brighton now. He had the opportunity to come with me, but Brighton was his choice. Leeds was mine.
answer: A surprising choice, some might say. Because you've been very vocal in your criticism of them over the years.

question: I have.
answer: You've accused players of dirty tactics, cheating, dissent, foul play. You called Norman Hunter, Norman "Bites yer legs" Hunter, you've said Peter Lorimer falls when no one touches him...

question: And I was right.
answer: I'm curious. Why do you now show such alacrity to joining them after such vituperative criticism of them for so long?

question: Goodness, it's going to take me half an hour to explain all those words for a start. ..they've been champions but they've not been good champions in the sense of wearing the crown well. They've not been loved. But then that's hardly surprising, given the type of operation there's been in place there. Football clubs are like families, footballers are sensitive people. I'd like to bring a little warmth into the set-up...
answer: "That type of operation?" I presume you're referring to Don Revie..

question: I am..
answer: ..who has long been regarded as a father figure in Leeds. And now you're coming in as the outsider, the enemy even, after all the things you've said in public, coming in and taking ouver as STEPfather. Don't you expect some degree of resentment to this?

question: I would accept and expect a strangeness, initially, it's perfectly normal. But it won't be long before they realise I'm a fair man. A kind man. And maybe under me they can experience what it's like to be in a happy family, after all.
answer: How can you be sure they weren't happy with Don all along?

question: They wouldn't have played football that way if they were happy.
answer: Directors have been waiting more than an hour. C'mon..

question: Morning lads! Lovely Yorkshire weather! I tell you makes me want to jump on a plane right back to Majorca!
answer: You're five days late!! And did you really need to say that about Majorca? You know he was Revie's first choice for getting your job.

question: Who? Johnny Giles?
answer: Club Captain. Don's son and heir. His first born. You're never going to get any love from him.

question: Great. Here's to happy fucking families. Any chance of a cup of tea, duck?
answer: They're waiting for you. Upstairs.

question: Who's that?
answer: The Directors.

question: For me? Why?
answer: For the board meeting.

question: Let them wait. Now, how about that cup of tea?
answer: Yours, Mr. Clough.

question: Not mine. I didn't put it there, did I?
answer: Mr. Revie's.

question: Let's get rid of it then, shall we? Chairs, too. The whole bloody lot. Think it would be best if there were nothing of his left here.
answer: I was. For thirteen happy years.

question: What's your name, pet?
answer: Jean, Sir. Jean Reid.

question: In which case, no offence duck, but there's nothing I want typed on paper from you other than your resignation.
answer: Come in, Brian.

question: What? No one going to offer me a drink? Like an undertakers in here.
answer: Why did you do it?

question: And I'm entitled to mine.
answer: And I'm entitled to MINE.

question: Thank you. I'm the best old one, too.
answer: ...I also did it under the assumption that you'd be coming here wanting the best for the club. For the city of Leeds. So why do I still get the feeling this is all about you and Don?

question: Don Revie's Leeds! Top of Division One! Here we bloody come!
answer: I can hear the cash registers now!

question: Happy days, Sir. Happy days.
answer: You're not wrong, Brian. Take the family out for a meal. Go to The Mumtaz. Tell `em I'm paying.

question: Put the fish and chips in the bin. Tonight's on Uncle Sam. We're going posh. Chicken fucking bhuna in town. General excitement. Everyone starts putting on their coats. Right, you two, I want Billy Bremner and Johnny Giles to be able to read Spick and span, understand? Wash these walls down. Give the floors a proper polish. I want it perfect. Like a fucking carpet. We've got proper footballers coming. Who know how to keep the ball on the deck. You know he'll be making a file on us. A dossier.
answer: Who?

question: Don Revie. Prepares a file on every game. Leaves nothing to chance. Knows every opponents formations. Strategies. Everything.
answer: I've heard he's a superstitious twat. Ey..! Help him, someone HELP him..!

question: We grew up just a few streets apart, you know. In Middlesborough, close to Ayrsome Park. He'll have known my street, Valley Road - probably bought sweets from Garnetts Factory, where my dad worked.
answer: Heard he wears the same suit to every game. His "lucky blue suit".

question: The best manager in the country, Don Revie. Played for Sunderland, like me, as a centre-forward, like me, and England, like me.
answer: C'mon, give it and go!

question: Now sent it out wide!
answer: What? He didn't fucking touch him! Ref! He DIVED! He fucking dived! Didn't say good-bye. Or pay me the respect of staying for a drink. Couldn't wait to get away.

question: Bloody cheats and all. Neither of those goals should have been allowed.
answer: Just going to have to beat them, Pete. Beat him it's the last thing I do.

question: We need to get into the same division first.
answer: We need someone with a good head. Experience.

question: I know. Our lot were like headless chickens out there today.
answer: First thing Monday morning, I want you to go and find me that player. A wise head. Right. Better go and make myself known. CLOUGH removes his jacket. JIMMY GORDON and CLOUGH's SONS watch as he walks out onto the training pitch... All right, gentlemen, gather around, please.

question: Fine thank you, Mr. Cussins.
answer: Not now, love - please?

question: But it might be Pete.
answer: Of course it's Pete.

question: But it might be important. C'mon, eat your carrots. For your Mother.
answer: You asked me to find a player with a good head. Experience. I've found one! He's perfect. Dave Mackay.

question: Dave Mackay?!? He's a hundred and fucking fifty.
answer: I admit he's not young.

question: Not young? He's old as fucking time!
answer: But he's clever, keeps the ball well. And passes it better than anyone alive. He's the one, Brian.

question: You sure?
answer: Never been more sure of anything in my life.

question: All right, I'll talk to Longson in the morning.
answer: We haven't got until morning. Hearts have already made him an offer. Want him as their manager. Apparently they've already agreed terms.

question: Well, what did you fucking call me for then?
answer: Because when I asked Bill Nick how done the deal was - he said ninety- nine per cent. CLOUGH's face.

question: Meaning he hasn't signed.
answer: Exactly.

question: Where would we play him?
answer: In the middle of the park. Somewhere he can see everything, use his loaf, and tell the kids what to do.

question: We'll play him as a sweeper, then.
answer: Aye.

question: Won't have to run about too much. And what's all this I hear about a tie shop?
answer: He's got a tie shop, hasn't he? In London. Which he spends two days a week at.

question: Fucking tie shop?
answer: It's his "nest egg". For the future.

question: No one's going to be wearing fucking ties in twenty years time. You know it's illegal. To sign someone on the sabbath.
answer: Is it? Then perhaps we should just shake on it today? And sign tomorrow?

question: What? And let Hearts in again in the morning? Fuck off. I'm not leaving here without a signature. CLOUGH and TAYLOR walk up the garden path..
answer: Hey, you would never have FOUND him if it weren't for me.

question: Good job we're both wearing ties.
answer: Who the bloody hell are you?

question: My name's Brian Clough, and I once had the pleasure of playing for England against you in an Under-23 match.
answer: I remember you now. You had a black eye, a right bloody shiner. And never stopped fucking talking! What are you doing here?

question: Come to talk to you about the Promised Land, Dave. Land of Milk and Honey. It's a little place up the M1 called Derby. May we come in?
answer: Dave Mackay??

question: You don't look happy, Uncle Sam.
answer: I'm not. What were you thinking? Going over my head like that? Why didn't you call?

question: Because you'd have said `no'.
answer: Bloody right I'd have said `no'. The man's bloody crocked.

question: Pete reckons he's good for three more years.
answer: Is he fuck. He's broken more bones than Evel Knievel.

question: Trust me, Mr. Chairman. It's money well spent.
answer: And who the FUCK are they?

question: That'd be Messrs. McGovern and O'Hare.
answer: Where did they come from?

question: My old stomping grounds. Hartlepools and Sunderland. Very reasonable, too.
answer: That'd be MY club, Brian. MY club.

question: Right, the team for today is Of course, it goes without saying I'd like you to continue as Club Captain.
answer: Never got it.

question: For fuck's sake.. Because losing wasn't enough, was it? You only had to be the first Englishman to be sent off at Wembley.
answer: Not fucking English.

question: There I am making a big song and dance to the media about our new approach. Our new attitude. Our new ethics. And you turn the place into fucking Verdun. My CAPTAIN.
answer: You can't do that! Mr. Revie always paid all our fines.

question: Well he's not fucking here now, is he?
answer: No, he's not.

question: Right, last time there was a whole division between you and Leeds. Not now. Not today. Today we're here as Second Division champions, and equals with Leeds. John McGovern and Billy Bremner, EQUALS. Kevin Hector and Johnny Giles, EQUALS. Alan Hinton and Peter Lorimer, John O'Hare and Paul Madely. EQUALS. Now, c'mon, chins up. Chests out. We can take this fucking lot.
answer: Arrogant twat..

question: But he's right. Five nothing. They made us look like fools today. And what was John O'Hare doing? Letting Madeley bully him like that.
answer: Yours.

question: He was all over the place. Like the Wandering Jew. Giving the ball to anyone BUT his own. We need a ball player, a natural in midfield. Who'll hold onto it. Keep possession. We're giving it away too easily.
answer: Someone like Colin Todd.

question: Oooh, now you're talking. Lovely pair of feet.
answer: I've heard he wants out of Sunderland, too. They're all jumping ship up there.

question: Well, go on then. Sign him.
answer: What? We can't. Longson's already told us. Club's in debt.

question: Bollocks to that. I've not brought us all the way to the First Division just to sit there mid-table, and be cannon fodder for sides like Leeds. Sign the man.
answer: Hang on, hang on, careful...

question: I'll handle bloody Longson.
answer: A hundred and seventy grand?!? For Colin fucking Todd?!?

question: Correction, the ALMIGHTY Colin Todd. The best technical footballer in the country.
answer: A salary of three hundred quid a week? You can't pay a footballer that!!

question: That's the way things are going, Uncle Sam. Football's all about money now.
answer: I told you never to go over my head again.

question: Had no choice. Windows opened up. You were in the bloody West Indies.
answer: WindowS? You mean there were others?!?

question: Messrs. Gemmell and Hennessy.
answer: For fucks SAKE!

question: Let me ask you a question, Uncle Sam. What did you come into football for?
answer: To support the football club in MY HOME TOWN. The club I've supported ALL

question: Well, I'm sure we all admire your loyalty...
answer: What I DIDN'T come into it for was to be lectured by a cocky little twat from the North East.

question: But the way I see it, there's no point being in this game unless you want to beat the best, and be the best, and that's all the people of Derby want. To see their team on top of the tree, Derby, Derby Uber Alles, and if it's really their interest you have at heart, not just impressing your friends in the Director's box, I suggest you keep your eyes on your road haulage business, keep your opinions to yourself and start signing some fucking cheques, there's a good lad. Leave the running of this football club to the professionals.
answer: But professionals DON'T run the club, Brian, the Chairman does. And if it's true, that football is all about money, and that's the way it's going, that's suits us Chairmen just fucking fine..because we're the ones who've got it. SAM LONGSON lights a cigar, and walks off.

question: Good lad. And enjoy it. You deserve to. You've worked hard this week.
answer: Be big. Be strong. Any chance I get, flatten Paul fucking Madely.

question: Good lad. He bullies you, you bully him back. And near post for the corners we worked on.
answer: Yes, Boss.

question: Understand what I want from you today, son?
answer: I should, Mr. Clough. It's simple enough.

question: Go on, let's hear it.
answer: "To be Colin fucking Todd, the best technical footballer in the country."

question: There, how could you forget that? Now come on.. Up and at `em! Congratulations, lads! Beautiful! That was as perfect a half of terrible football as I've ever seen. The plan you've obviously been hatching to get me the sack has worked a treat, so you deserve a little celebration...
answer: No, Boss.

question: Then why the fuck did you give it to their most dangerous player, Johnny fucking Giles?
answer: I didn't see him.

question: That open goal? Looked like a deliberate fucking miss to me. A miss to get your manager the sack.
answer: No.

question: No what?
answer: No, Boss.

question: The amount of bloody money I paid for you, I must have been out of my mind. You can't even keep on your feet.
answer: No, Boss.

question: And..?
Who scored?
answer: O'Hare. A brace. Oh, Brian, you should have seen his first. Turns Bremner inside out, nutmegs Madeley for good measure. It was beautiful. You'd think he'd been born in Rio de Janeiro, not Aber-bloody-deen..

question: They were just nervous. Shitting themselves. You could tell.
answer: You're a bloody genius. I tell you what, Bri - if we can beat this lot, we can go all the way.

question: Don Revie? Ooooh. Don't mention that name to me. I hate to mention him why? Because he's a very talented man and I don't like him. And er... it makes the game go round. Half the country don't like a Labour government. It just happens that the other half do. Because I can't tell you. It's impossible. We'd get closed down, David. By your profession, John, yeah. And a whole lot of it wrong. Good lad. Thank you for the compliment. It's very, very difficult when you get asked a question like that. Suprised, David..but more than surprised, delighted. It's nice isn't it. For the good guys to win for once. Beating Leeds United, obviously. Always a particular pleasure that. Niggled me, David, it's absolutely made me blazing. To be honest, I know what I want to achieve, I know what the people of Derby want us to achieve, but when you've got a chairman not wanting to put his hand in his pocket... I say, "How do you think it should be done?" We talk about it for twenty minutes, then we decide I was right.
answer: Are you going to stop it?

question: No, I want to fight him! It was. Thank you.. What? September 30th? That's more than a month? Thats six bloody weeks?? C'mon, double the fine. Treble it. Anything. Don't suspend him for that long. He's my Captain. The best player I've got.
answer: Hello?

question: I suppose you've heard!
answer: God...what time is it?

question: Suspended for eleven bloody games!!
answer: I know. You're buggered. Billy Bremner's the heart and soul of that team.

question: Plus Mike Jones and Eddie Gray are injured.
answer: Like I said. You're buggered.

question: What do I do, Pete? I need new players. Tell me who to buy.
answer: No, Brian.

question: Help me. C'mon, we'll sort this place out together. You and me. Turn it around.
answer: It's too late. I'd have helped you once. But not now. Not after what was said. We're on our own now. Each man for himself. Remember?

question: Well, look who it is! Come to raid my larder? Or just missing the place?
answer: McGovern and O'Hare. I've spoken to them on the phone. They want to come and play for me.

question: Aye, and you can have `em. A hundred and fifty thousand pound for the pair.
answer: Cheeky sod! They're not worth a penny more than seventy.

question: But you're desperate now, aren't you? Having lost to Stoke and Birmingham.. All, right, since it's you..I'll knock ten grand off.
answer: Give you a hundred grand.

question: One thirty. Final offer. CLOUGH is about to explode, then..
answer: All right. Done.

question: Two wins from two. What's not to enjoy? You?
answer: Loving it. Different class, Leeds. Proper club. BIG club.

question: Demand results there, though, Brian.
answer: Hey, it's `Boss' to you.

question: Not any more.
answer: I bought you when you were crocked, you fat bastard. And gave you the two best years of your career. It will always be `Boss' to you.

question: Why would I do that?
answer: Exorcise the bloody place. Get rid of me.

question: Why? You're not here anymore, are you? Be a waste of a perfectly good desk.
answer: Fucking Scot.

question: Fucking Scot.
answer: McGovern and O'Hare? Can't believe he actually sold them to you. It must be true, then..

question: What?
answer: The rumour that he's after buying Duncan Mackenzie. It's why he needs the money.

question: Who's Duncan Mackenzie? Is that Duncan Mackenzie?
answer: Yes. This is he.

question: Now listen to me. You go get your coat and your skates on because you're coming to meet me at the Victoria Hotel in Sheffield in half and hour. And Duncan?
answer: Yes, Mr. Clough.

question: Because of the way we play!!! And you, Mr. Mackenzie, you scored twenty-eight goals last season. You'll score me twenty-nine goals this.
answer: Yes, Mr. Clough.

question: Do you know how many goals I scored before I got injured?
answer: I'm sorry, Mr. Clough. I don't.

question: Two hundred and fifty-one.
answer: I'm sorry, Mr. Clough, I don't.

question: Have a guess. Go on...
answer: Three hundred?

question: Two hundred and seventy-four! Now what do you think about that?
answer: Is that a record, Mr. Clough?

question: `Course it's a bloody record. Need to know what they say about me. Who's making trouble. Who the ringleaders are.
answer: Yes, Mr. Clough.

question: Want you to help me clear this place out. Make it MY team, understand. OUR team. Clean it up and clear it out once and for all.
answer: Yes, Mr. Clough.

question: Now c'mon, drink up. We're off to meet the press.
answer: Yes, Mr. Clough.

question: And Duncan..?
answer: Yes, Mr. Clough?

question: It's "Boss" from now on. There's a good lad.
answer: Yes, Mr. Clough.

question: I haven't forgotten.
answer: Well, you haven't told us a single thing about how QPR will play. Mr Revie would have files and dossiers prepared. Had the reserves playing the Rangers way all week. Had the first team looking out for this and that.

question: Bollocks to Mr. Revie! You're professional footballers. Stop Stan Bowles! That's all you need to know about QPR. And I don't have to justify myself to you. Not how or when I conduct training. Not who I buy or pick to play.
answer: No. Not to us. But come Saturday afternoon, there'll be 40,000 people here who you DO have to justify yourself, to.

question: Sorry, lads.
answer: Hello?

question: You must be loving this. Loving every minute.
answer: Who is this?

question: Watching it all fall apart. It's Brian Clough.
answer: What?

question: They won't play for me. Your boys. Your bastard sons. And never will.
answer: Are you drunk, man? It's two in the morning. What do you want? Why are you ringing me here?

question: They're loyal to you. Thought you'd like to know that. Loyal to Big Daddy Don..
answer: For God's sake go to sleep. Where's you dignity, man? And don't call here again.

question: Get me today's team sheet, will you?
answer: What's up, Uncle Sam? Bit below stairs for you here, isn't it? Taken a wrong turn somewhere?

question: Just seen the team sheet. Hinton, O'Hare, Todd, Mackay. That's our strongest side.
answer: Of course it's our strongest side. It's Leeds United. Would you prefer I sent out the apprentices?

question: We're at Juventus mid-week. Semi-final of the European Cup. Biggest night in the club's history!! Couldn't you just field...
answer: What?

question: Y'know...
answer: A weaker side? Am I hearing right? Is the CHAIRMAN of this football club seriously asking his manager to LOSE?

question: You know what I mean..
answer: Against their biggest rivals?

question: The Chairman of this football club is asking his manager to be pragmatic. Manage his resources. Prioritise. We've embarked on a huge program of refurbishment and improvements. New stands. Better floodlights. We need a good run in Europe to pay for it.
answer: I'm going to pretend I didn't hear a word of this.

question: We've still got twenty minutes before kick-off. I'd reconsider if I were you. I wouldn't want my employer to be unhappy..
answer: My employer?

question: Chairman of Derby County. And Chairman LONG before you ever showed up.
answer: That's right. You were Chairman of Derby County before I came here. I remember that. When Derby County were at the fucking foot of the Second Division, when nobody had heard of them for twenty years and nobody had heard of Sam bloody Longson ever. Full stop. And that's where you'd still fucking be if it wasn't for me; at the foot of the bloody Second Division, where nobody remembered you and nobody had heard of you. There would BE no Derby County without me, no league title, no Champions of England; not without Brian Clough.

question: Disappointed? Not a bit. My players were heroic out there tonight. Effectively we were playing the Italian champions with a reserve team. That many of our first team are injured... ...it's what happens if you have a Chairman who authorizes a multi- million pound refurbishment of the director's box and hospitality suites before he pays for a proper squad. Suppose it depends on your priorities. Players or prawn sandwiches? I know which I'd prefer. I know which honest, working class Derby supporters would prefer, too..
answer: Billy Bremner, Boss.

question: Who else?
answer: Norman Hunter.

question: Who else?
answer: Eddie Gray.

question: Who else?
answer: Peter Lorimer.

question: And that all thing's considered they were all a lot happier under...
answer: Under who?

question: Yes, Boss.
answer: That he's the boss? The Guvnor? The Capi di Tutti Fucking Capi?

question: You'll have complimentary cars when you deserve a compliment. Right now you don't deserve a complimentary bicycle between you.
answer: What are you doing here? Aren't you supposed to be in that hotel in Leeds?

question: I couldn't stand it for another night.
answer: What? So you drove all the way? What time will you have to get up in the morning...

question: Half five.
answer: Do I?

question: Forgotten what a woman smells like.
answer: Not like bloody men. That's for sure.

question: Where you been? I was about to send out a search party.
answer: Look, Mr. Cussins, I know it's not been the best of starts, but in my defence, there are a couple of things I'd like to say...

question: This is Martin Hughes. He runs Mercedes here in the North.
answer: What?

question: We hear that's what you like to drive. A Mercedes?
answer: It's..what I used to drive at Derby. Yes.

question: Heart attack, eh?
answer: Had it three weeks ago, they reckon.

question: We have. Longson's tried to put a gagging order on me, of course. "Any further utterances in public or appearances in the media by Brian Clough will be met with instant dismissal."
answer: Well, I hope you take notice. And act accordingly.

question: Would you like to hear my contrite reply?
answer: WHAT??!?

question: What do you think?
answer: I don't want to resign.

question: No. Nor do I. Don't worry, they'll never let us. We just won them the championship. But it will strengthen our position and force them to get rid of Longson.
answer: What? Oh, no, Brian. They'll never do THAT. He's Chairman.

question: I can't do it, Pete. I can't work with my hands tied, a Chairman telling me what I can or cannot do.
answer: You're picking the wrong enemy. The enemy's not Longson. It's Revie. And your obsession with Leeds.

question: Don't be daft. We won the league, Pete. We're top dogs in Derby now. And Longson can't stand it. That's the problem.
answer: No, it's not. It's YOU. This monster in you. This mad ambition. It comes and goes. Sometimes it's good...a fire, that stirs everything up, and then there's this...this thing that takes you over...and destroys everything that is good in your life. TAYLOR's face...

question: What are you doing? You weren't supposed to accept our resignations.
answer: `Shouldn't bloody well offer them, then.

question: I only did because of HIM! You can't get rid of us. It'd be a disaster for the club. For the whole of Derby.
answer: You can't keep shooting your mouth off the way you have been...or issuing these ultimatums..

question: You can't do this! It's madness!
answer: The decision stands. And don't even think of a settlement. You're getting nowt.

question: We're going to create a footballing dynasty here. Derby could be one of the greats alongside United, Liverpool, Leeds..
answer: Car keys on the table and out!

question: Does none of you have the guts to stop this?
answer: Now! And don't show your faces here again!

question: But not Dave Mackay.
answer: What? Dave MACKAY?

question: It's in the evening paper.
answer: I signed that fat fuck - saved his professional life. Gave him two more years as a player, as my captain. Dave Mackay? He wouldn't fucking DARE!

question: Why did you do it? I love this place, Brian. I'm happy here. So are you.
answer: It's not over yet, Pete. The lawyers are issuing a writ tomorrow. Against Longson. The players are calling a meeting. There's talk of them coming out on strike. There's protest marches scheduled for this week-end.

question: Come on. "Oh, I don't like to be beside the seaside.."
answer: C'mon, just give it a chance.

question: Brighton and Hove Albion? Have you seen where they are? Bottom of the third division.
answer: And we can get them out of there. Like that. We did it with Hartlepools. We did it with Derby.

question: We cared about Hartlepools and Derby. We're from the North, Pete. What do we care about Brighton? Bloody Southerners. Look where we are. We're almost in France.
answer: Hey, they've got money, this lot. And ambition. And get a lungful of that air. It'd be good for my health.

question: You can't manage a team that's not your own people. Not what you know. Anyway the Protest Movement in Derby is still in full flow. We could still get our jobs back.
answer: No, we won't. It's over, Brian. They'll never take us back. Not now.

question: What about proper clubs? Like Manchester United? Or Spurs? Or England, now Alf's gone. Wouldn't you fancy that?
answer: No one's rung, have they? You've scared them all off.

question: It's only been a couple of weeks.
answer: C'mon. Just listen to them? Please? For me?

question: C'mon. Just listen to them? Please? For me?
answer: Sign today, I'll give you a bonus of seven grand. Each.

question: Seven grand? Y'hear that, Brian?
answer: Plus a salary that exceeds by twenty percent what Derby were paying you.

question: But those are first division wages.
answer: First division's where I want this club to be.

question: Are you sure you can afford it?
answer: Are you sure you're worth it?

question: Cheeky sod.
answer: Take as long as you like.

question: Two weeks. Somewhere hot. On you.
answer: I'll even throw in the bloody trunks.

question: Who's looking? Then what are you doing here, Keith? Because from what I'm reading in my paper, and from what I hear on the jungle drums, you've got a bit of a problem at home with your manager flirting with the England job. `Ey, it says it right here.
answer: Bloody hell. But we HATE Leeds.

question: It's the top flight, Pete. The First Division.
answer: But we've given Brighton our word. And they've paid us the money.

question: We can pay BACK the money. Bollocks to bloody Brighton. I'd go mad. We'd ALL go mad down there.
answer: Please...give it a year. Give it a chance.

question: A year? It'd be death. Death for us all.
answer: Mike Bamber is a good man..

question: Oh, do me a favour..
answer: He had faith in us, offered us a job when no one would.

question: He offered us a job. And now someone else has offered us a better one..and not just anyone. The best team in the country. C'mon, Pete, you know what that means.. It'd be the Charity Shield at Wembley in a months time. The European Cup after..
answer: Yes, but even if we won them it would always be Revie's achievements. HIS team..

question: What? And you'd sooner fester down there? With all those fucking Tories? In that blue-rinse retirement home by the sea?
answer: Yes, Brighton is a small club..

question: Fucking midgets.
answer: But at least we'd be together, you and me. We could build them up. Make them our own. Like we did with Hartlepools. Like we did with Derby.

question: And then what? Bottle again as soon as it comes to the big time. That's always been the trouble with you, Pete. No ambition.
answer: And that's the trouble with you. Too much ambition. Too much greed. Too much everything.

question: You knock it, but it's done you proud over the years. My "ambition". Without me - you'd still be stuck in Burton Albion. On the arse of the footballing earth.
answer: But without you I'd still have a job in Derby. A job and a home that I love. Yes, Brian - you're the shop window, I'll grant you that. The razzle and the bloody dazzle. But I'm the goods at the back. And without me, without someone to save you from yourself, you're not just half.. ...you're nothing.

question: I'm nothing? I'm nothing?? Don't make me laugh? So what does that make you, Taylor? Something?? You're half of nothing!! Nothing's parasite! A big fat pilot fish that FEEDS on nothing!! A bloody nobody!! The forgotten man!! History's fucking afterthought!!
answer: Well, let's see, shall we?

question: Let's be honest. It's not working, is it?
answer: What's not working? I haven't been here five minutes, so how can anything be working yet?

question: Still...the players aren't happy. We're not happy.
answer: So what do you want to do about it?

question: If it's not working, then we'll have to part company.
answer: Fine. It'll cost you twenty-five grand.

question: What? For six weeks work?
answer: Plus three and a half grand for Jimmy Gordon. And an agreement that Leeds United will pay both our income taxes for the next three years.

question: That's bloody criminal.
answer: No, what's criminal, Mr. Cussins, is the way you as Chairman asked me to leave the room like that in front of the players. Your MANAGER. Going behind my back like that.

question: I admit, that was wrong.
answer: And you can throw in the Merc and all.

question: The sad thing is, it won't work. You can't change a manager like a pair of socks. It'll happen once, to me - and never again.
answer: Thanks for agreeing to this.

question: No problem. What's this? We expecting guests?
answer: Good evening. Tonight the football world was stunned by the news that Brian Clough has been sacked as manager of Leeds United. We'll be talking not just to Brian Clough, but also to the man he replaced, who's success he couldn't emulate, Don Revie.

question: Being very, very honest, I think it was a difficult job for anyone to do. But I do feel Brian Clough, I won't call him Clough because I won't take him down like that..
answer: Thank you.

question: ...I do feel he made it harder for himself than he need have.
answer: How did I do that, Don?

question: Shooting his mouth off about how dirty my players were.
answer: Well, you WERE dirty, Don!

question: That's not true. The last four seasons, we've topped the charts for entertaining football.
answer: And before that, you also topped ALL the disciplinary charts. You should have been docked points and sent DOWN to the second Division.

question: Of course it did! The things he said? Why, man? Why did you take the job in the first place?
answer: Because I thought it was the best job in the country.

question: Of course it was the best job in the country.
answer: I was taking over the League Champions.

question: You were. You were taking over the best bunch of players you'd ever seen.
answer: And I fancied winning the league, and winning Europe, and doing it better than you.

question: There's no way you COULD win it better.
answer: But that's the only hope I've got.

question: I only lost four matches..
answer: Well, I can only lose three.

question: No, no, no, no.
answer: And still play attractive, clean football. Without cheating!

question: Well, we're very different people, Don and I. We have different styles. In football and in life. I'm a warm man. An idealist. I do believe in faeries, and that is my outlook. Don is different. There's a hardness to him. A hardness. Maybe he's not even aware of it. But he's a cold person.
answer: You don't KNOW me!

question: And that lack of warmth. That coldness was there. Permeated the club when I arrived.
answer: I totally refute that. The atmosphere at Leeds was like a family. A happy family. You ask any of my players. I signed most of them personally. Knew their backgrounds. Their parents. Their streets. I was a father to them. In that club every morning. Massaging those boys. Did you do that for them?

question: They would never have let me.
answer: Did you try? You didn't even try. I soaped those boys down with my own hands. You just went to Leeds with no thought for the club, no thought for the players. Just on some kind of mad personal vendetta with me.

question: Well are you surprised? What else was I going to do?? After what you did...
answer: What did I do?

question: C'mon, Don. You know exactly.
answer: Never! Matter of principle! I always shake the other manager's hand!

question: You shook Peter Taylor's hand, and my trainer, Jimmy Gordon's.
answer: Then I probably didn't see you!!

question: No, you saw me Don. But considered me beneath you. Looked down on me. And dismissed me. Just like you did every other club and every other manager in the country.
answer: Never would I knowingly refuse to shake a colleague's hand. The truth is, I probably just didn't know who you were.

question: "Didn't know who I was!" Pull the other one.
answer: It's the truth.

question: Well, you certainly know it NOW.
answer: Oh, we ALL know it now. We know you as the man who's constant outbursts, his defaming of fellow professionals, have brought this game, this beautiful game into disrepute. Who had one of the best jobs in the country, at Derby, and managed to get the sack. Who had one of the best partners in the game, in Peter Taylor, and threw him away. Who was given the greatest gift in British football Leeds United, a team that in ten years hasn't finished outside the top four, and took them to the bottom of the first division. Yes, it's fair to say we all know who you are now.

question: Well, let's see where we are in a year's time, Donald Revie.
answer: Dear oh dear..

question: Let's see where we both are in five!
answer: Thank you, Austin.
